skill.name: gh-issue-fix-flow
skill.description: End-to-end GitHub issue fix workflow using gh, local code changes, builds/tests, and git push. Use when asked to take an issue number, inspect the issue via gh, implement a fix, run XcodeBuildMCP builds/tests, commit with a closing message, and push.

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only workflow documentation. No executable code, network operations, or file system access beyond standard development tools described in the workflow instructions.

content.value_statement: Manually resolving GitHub issues requires navigating multiple tools and remembering each step. This skill provides a structured workflow that guides AI assistants from issue intake through code changes, testing, and git push with consistent results.
actual_capabilities: Inspect GitHub issues via gh CLI with full context and comments
Locate relevant code using ripgrep (rg) with line numbers
Implement minimal code fixes aligned with existing architecture
Run XcodeBuildMCP builds and tests for macOS and iOS simulators
Create commits with proper closing message format (closes #id)
Push changes and report results with test outcomes
limitations: Requires gh CLI and git to be installed and authenticated
XcodeBuildMCP must be available for iOS/macOS builds and tests
Does not create pull requests or handle merge conflicts
Limited to repos where the user has push access

use_cases.title: Automate issue resolution
use_cases.description: Standardize the complete cycle from issue intake to verified fix deployment

prompt_templates.title: Simple issue fix
prompt_templates.prompt: Fix GitHub issue #123 in owner/repo. Use gh-issue-fix-flow workflow.

prompt_templates.title: Full context fix
prompt_templates.prompt: Resolve issue #456 in user/repo. The issue involves a crash in the login flow. Follow gh-issue-fix-flow: inspect issue, locate code, implement fix, build and test with XcodeBuildMCP, commit with closing message, and push.

prompt_templates.title: Complex debugging
prompt_templates.prompt: Debug and fix issue #789 in org/repo. The bug causes data loss on sync. Use gh-issue-fix-flow: get full issue context including comments, search the codebase for sync-related code, implement minimal fix, run comprehensive tests via XcodeBuildMCP, commit properly, and push with summary.

prompt_templates.title: Batch processing
prompt_templates.prompt: Process these GitHub issues: #100 (crash on launch), #101 (typo in UI), #102 (memory leak). Apply gh-issue-fix-flow to each, run appropriate tests, and provide a consolidated report of all changes and test results.

best_practices: Always run builds and tests before committing to catch issues early
Use targeted test schemes instead of full test suites when possible
Include the issue number in commit messages for automatic closing
anti_patterns: Skipping the build step and going straight to commit
Making large, unrelated changes instead of minimal focused fixes
Not checking git status for unrelated changes before staging

faq.question: What tools does this skill require?
faq.answer: Requires gh CLI, git, and XcodeBuildMCP server. gh and git must be authenticated with repo access.

faq.question: Can this skill handle cross-platform projects?
faq.answer: Yes. For iOS projects, it runs iOS simulator tests when macOS tests fail due to deployment target mismatches.

faq.question: Does this skill create pull requests?
faq.answer: No. The skill ends at git push. Pull request creation is not included in the workflow.

faq.question: Is my code and issue data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. All operations run locally using standard CLI tools. No code or data is sent to external services beyond normal git/gh communication.

faq.question: What if builds or tests fail?
faq.answer: The workflow reports failures transparently. It does not hide warnings or errors. You can iterate on fixes until tests pass.

faq.question: How is this different from manual issue resolution?
faq.answer: This skill provides a consistent, step-by-step workflow that ensures no steps are missed. It standardizes how issues are investigated, fixed, tested, and committed.
